2. A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after experiencing sudden onset of double vision and difficulty swallowing over the past two weeks. His parents have noticed his speech becoming slurred and that he occasionally chokes while drinking liquids. Neurological examination reveals bilateral ptosis, impaired gag reflex, and decreased strength in the right upper limb. He also demonstrates truncal ataxia and subtle facial asymmetry. Brain MRI shows an infiltrative, expansile lesion centered in the medulla oblongata with increased T2 signal and mild contrast enhancement. No significant hydrocephalus is present, but there is compression of the fourth ventricle. The patient has no previous medical issues and is fully vaccinated with normal developmental history. These findings suggest a diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma, consistent with childhood brainstem astrocytoma, warranting biopsy and multidisciplinary management.

I might also be nervous or unsure about how to explain all this.

ANSWER: Um, I started feeling really strange a couple of weeks ago. My eyes have been acting weird, like blurry or double, and I sometimes choke when I drink. I couldn’t really talk right and feel kind of weak on one side.
